articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
The BMA is ‘no longer in dispute’ with the Government and NHS England and has paused collective action after accepting a GP contract deal for 2025/26. Yesterday, the union’s GP Committee England agreed a deal ‘in principle’ which will see almost £800m invested into the global sum, as part of a £969m total funding uplift
The post GP collective action paused as BMA ‘no longer in dispute’ with Government appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP collective action paused as BMA ‘no longer in dispute’ with Government

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
GP practices will be contractually required to keep their online consultation tool ‘open’ during core hours regardless of capacity. From October, practices will need to keep the tool open from 8am to 6:30pm for ‘non-urgent appointment requests, medication queries and admin requests’. This forms part of the 2025/26 GP contract which is due to come
The post GP practices to be required keep online consultations ‘open’ during core hours appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP practices to be required keep online consultations ‘open’ during core hours

articles.author: Jaimie Kaffash
articles.description:
The BMA GP Committee and NHS England have agreed changes to the contract for the first time in four years. Here are the major headlines There will be £800m invested into the global sum. According to the BMA, the deal represents a 7.2% cash growth in contract funding. In total it’s estimated Global Sum per
The post At a glance: All the headlines from the 2025/26 contract agreement appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: At a glance: All the headlines from the 2025/26 contract agreement

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
Pulse editor Sofia Lind on why the new Labour Government’s successful first GP contract negotiation is merely a promising start Credit where credit is due. It has been four years since the BMA’s GP Committee last agreed to a proposed contract deal from the Government. Whilst there’s still financial detail to be ironed out, and some of
The post Streeting passes first GP test but the next few months will be pivotal appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Streeting passes first GP test but the next few months will be pivotal

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
NHS England has confirmed that a £20 payment for advice and guidance (A&G) requests will be made available to GP practices by a national enhanced service from April. The 2025/26 GP contract offer, accepted by the BMA and announced this morning, set out further details of the £80m A&G funding pot, which was first revealed
The post Contract details new enhanced service to fund advice and guidance (A&G) appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Contract details new enhanced service to fund advice and guidance (A&G)

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
NHS England will remove 32 QOF indicators and invest their funding into global sum, childhood vaccinations and cardiovascular prevention as part of the next GP contract. The indicators that will be removed include establishing and maintaining registers of cancer patients, and of patients with a learning disability, dementia, heart failure, hypertension and arterial disease (see box).
The post Large chunk of QOF retired to fund global sum and immunisation fees rise appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Large chunk of QOF retired to fund global sum and immunisation fees rise

articles.author: Sofia Lind
articles.description:
NHS England’s national director for primary care Dr Amanda Doyle hails the first negotiated – rather than imposed – GP contract deal in years. This is the first time in four years that the GP contract has been accepted as proposed and I hope it will be seen as positive for practices, primary care networks
The post Dr Amanda Doyle: ‘Extensive talks were held to find a fair GP contract deal’ appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: Dr Amanda Doyle: ‘Extensive talks were held to find a fair GP contract deal’

articles.author: Eliza Parr
articles.description:
Funding for recruiting GPs via the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) will no longer be ringfenced while salaries will see a boost, under the 2025/26 GP contract. The contract offer, accepted by the BMA yesterday, will see NHS England ‘increase flexibility’ by combining funding for GPs, which is currently ringfenced, with the pot for all
The post New contract removes ARRS GP funding ringfence and increases salaries appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: New contract removes ARRS GP funding ringfence and increases salaries

articles.author: Anna Colivicchi
articles.description:
GPs will be required to publish a ‘patient charter’ setting out the standard of care they are contracted to provide, and will see a new incentive to boost patient continuity. Practices will now be paid to identify those that ‘would benefit most from continuity of care’, via amendments to the Capacity and Access Improvement (CAIP)
The post GP practices to publish ‘patient charter’ and receive continuity of care incentive appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: GP practices to publish ‘patient charter’ and receive continuity of care incentive

articles.author: Mollie Fraser-Andrews
articles.description:
GP trainer and palliative care lead Dr Nicolas Alexander advises on the key non-pain symptoms that patients experience during palliative and end-of-life care, and how they can be managed. Complete the full module on Pulse 365 today This module will enhance your knowledge of the management of palliative care in general practice, including: 1. What
The post CPD: Key questions on non-pain symptom control in palliative care appeared first on Pulse Today.
articles.title: CPD: Key questions on non-pain symptom control in palliative care

articles.description: An updated 'statement of financial entitlements' (SFE) for general practice in 2025/26 confirms that global sum funding per patient will rise to £121.79 - and sets out for the first time details of uplifts to locum reimbursements.
articles.title: Government unveils detail of 2025/26 GP contract funding

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to Dr Charlie Andrews, a GP partner and a GP with an extended role in gastroenterology, about the programme he's developed to train GPs with extended roles in gastroenterology and how the NHS could benefit from expanding this approach across the country.
articles.title: Podcast: How GPs with extended roles could reshape the NHS

articles.description: The government should set clear milestones for moving more NHS funding into primary care and simplify the GP contract to deliver plans for more healthcare outside hospitals, a think tank has warned.
articles.title: GPs need larger share of NHS cash and fewer hoops to jump through, says think tank

articles.description: All referrals for advice and guidance under the new directed enhanced service (DES) must be GP-led and practices will need to develop a protocol for identifying appropriate patients, according to new guidance.
articles.title: NHS England sets out details of new advice and guidance enhanced service

articles.description: Funding for the additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) will expand by more than £256m in 2025/26, taking its total value to almost £1.7bn, NHS England has confirmed.
articles.title: ARRS funding will rise to almost £1.7bn in 2025/26, NHS England confirms

articles.description: The landmark 2018 GP contract agreed between the BMA and the Scottish government has failed to deliver on key commitments to tackle workload and financial pressure, a watchdog has warned.
articles.title: Scotland's 2018 GP contract has 'failed to deliver', watchdog warns

articles.description: Scrapping NHS England could remove a barrier to GP contract reform and help bring thousands of available GPs into the workforce, the BMA council chair has suggested.
articles.title: Scrapping NHS England could remove barrier to GP contract reform, says BMA

articles.description: A programme to train GPs with extended roles (GPwERs) in gastroenterology is cost-effective and could help shift services from secondary care to the community, according to an evaluation of the scheme.
articles.title: More GPs with extended roles could supercharge shift of services out of hospitals

articles.description: National insurance costs that kick in from next week risk practice closures and staff redundancies despite the funding uplift for general practice under the 2025/26 GP contract, GP campaigners have warned ahead of the government's spring budget statement.
articles.title: NI costs could force practice closures, GPs warn ahead of spring budget

articles.description: Practices have been urged to check that their staff’s professional regulation status is up to date after a GP had to review 1,800 consultations delivered by a nurse whose registration had lapsed, in a case that could have had major ramifications for the practice as a whole.
articles.title: GP practice forced to review 1,800 consultations after nurse registration lapse

articles.description: General practice should prioritise offering more face-to-face appointments with GPs over rapid access to drive improvements in patient satisfaction, a study suggests.
articles.title: Face-to-face GP appointments more important than rapid access for patient satisfaction

articles.description: GP practices are facing increased workload and patient complaints because of slow progress on reducing the NHS hospital waiting list, doctors' leaders have warned.
articles.title: GP workload 'exacerbated' by slow progress on cutting NHS waits

articles.description: One in four GP partners have cut their working hours to avoid 'absurd' pension tax penalties - denying the NHS around 4m GP appointments so far this year, the BMA has warned.
articles.title: Millions of GP appointments lost to 'absurd' pension tax rules, warns BMA

articles.description: A GP practice in Peterborough has been forced to close temporarily and move staff to another site, after a 'security risk' that led to a woman being charged by police.
articles.title: GP practice closed for nearly two weeks after 'security risk'

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses the latest news affecting general practice.
articles.title: Podcast: Green light for GP contract reform, farewell NHS England, alternatives to GP partnership

articles.description: Contract termination notices issued almost five years ago against a London GP who refused to co-operate with a PCN have finally been withdrawn, but he now fears a renewed dispute.
articles.title: ICB drops bid to terminate GP's contract over PCN stance

articles.description: Health and social care secretary Wes Streeting has hired former GP Sir John Oldham to advise the DHSC on plans to shift more care into the community and create a neighbourhood NHS.
articles.title: Streeting appoints GP to lead on government neighbourhood NHS plans

articles.description: The introduction of physician associate (PA) roles to the NHS has been a 'total system failure' that gambles with patient safety, the BMA has warned, as it submitted more than 30 recommendations for changes to a government review.
articles.title: BMA demands new name and clear scope of practice for physician associates

articles.description: GP practice staff have revealed they have been ‘spat at, sworn at’ and ‘received threats’ while at work, as an anti-abuse campaign launched to encourage patients to be kind.
articles.title: Anti-abuse campaign launched after GP practice staff ‘spat and sworn' at

articles.description: The government has committed to talks on a major overhaul of the GP contract within the current parliament in a move that finalises agreement with the BMA over the near £1bn contract deal for 2025/26.
articles.title: Government commits to talks on major new GP contract to keep 2025/26 deal on track

articles.description: GP leaders are preparing for an emergency vote that could plunge general practice into 'formal industrial dispute' with the government, threatening the near £1bn contract deal for 2025/26.
articles.title: Contract deal on the brink as GPs prepare for emergency vote

articles.description: Lawyers representing physician associates (PAs) have begun filing legal claims in a 'landmark group action' against GP practices, the RCGP and the BMA after guidance that backed strict limits on the roles.
articles.title: GP practices, RCGP and BMA face legal claims over physician associate jobs

articles.description: Doctors' leaders have urged the government to fix the 'broken' student finance system - warning that nine in 10 medical students say their mental health has been affected by their financial situation.
articles.title: Tight finances hit medical students' mental health, BMA warns

articles.description: Draft NICE guidance that backs annual BMI and waist-to-height ratio checks for adults with long-term conditions risks driving up workload for 'severely overstretched' GPs, the RCGP has warned.
articles.title: GP workload warning as NICE backs BMI checks on patients with long-term conditions

articles.description: NICE has backed annual BMI and waist-to-height ratio checks for adults with long-term conditions in draft guidance published this week, as part of a drive to boost preventive care.
articles.title: NICE backs annual BMI check for patients with long-term conditions in draft advice

articles.description: Two GPs have been named in a revamped executive team that will lead the health service through the abolition of NHS England.
articles.title: Two GPs named in revamped NHS executive team

articles.description: The government and NHS England are using the Office for National Statistics (ONS) Health Insight Survey to track improvements in GP access. GPonline looks at which ICB areas have the highest ratings and which are improving fastest.
articles.title: Map: Which areas are performing best on the government's GP access benchmark?

articles.description: The RCGP has changed its stance on assisted dying after its council voted to move to a position of neither supporting nor opposing a change in the law on the issue.
articles.title: RCGP moves to neutral position on assisted dying

articles.description: Many health leaders have said scrapping NHS England makes sense to reduce costs and duplication at the 'centre' of the health service, but warned that the move risks diverting attention from vital work to improve NHS services. So what are the changes likely to mean for GPs?
articles.title: What does NHS England's abolition mean for general practice?

articles.description: GPs in Scotland could be balloted on industrial action this summer if ministers do not offer sufficient assurances on boosting GP funding at a crunch meeting later this month, the Scottish BMA GP committee chair has said
articles.title: Scottish GPs could be balloted on industrial action this summer

articles.description: Talking General Practice speaks to BMA Scotland GP committee chair Dr Iain Morrison about the critical challenges facing general practice in Scotland.
articles.title: Podcast: Dr Iain Morrison on securing a better future for Scotland's GPs

articles.description: The government has announced plans to scrap NHS England, with work to transfer its functions into the DHSC beginning immediately in a major acceleration of health service reform.
articles.title: Starmer scraps NHS England to bring health service 'back into democratic control'

articles.description: The NHS pension scheme will change from April to clarify how GP and non-GP partners provide their annual certificate of pensionable earnings, the government has confirmed.
articles.title: NHS pension scheme updates rules on GP pensionable earnings from April

articles.description: Thousands of people were not invited to NHS screening programmes - with 10 going on to die from cancer - after problems with the GP registration process, officials have said.
articles.title: Thousands of patients miss cancer screening due to GP registration problems

articles.description: The BMA has called on NHS England to introduce a mandatory scope of practice for physician associates (PAs) and anaesthesia associates (AAs) after a review found a lack of evidence the roles are safe.
articles.title: PAs need 'mandatory scope of practice' to avoid safety scandal, warns BMA

articles.description: Despite record numbers of appointments in general practice, access remains among patients' top concerns - and NHS officials have named improving it among the health service's key priorities for the year ahead. After a period of intense criticism over access, however, data suggest general practice is now turning things around.
articles.title: How GPs are turning around problems with access and patient satisfaction

articles.description: 'Devastated' practices in Lothian have been forced to make staff redundant after up to five-figure increases in premises fees - in a crisis GPs fear could spread across Scotland.
articles.title: 'Devastated' practices lay off staff after five-figure premises cost hike

articles.description: A shortage of capital funding for community services could make government plans to move care out of hospital unachievable, local NHS leaders have warned.
articles.title: Moving care to community won't work without more capital funding, providers warn

articles.description: GPs have been asked to share information about their experience of working with physician associates (PAs) as part of an ongoing government-commissioned review.
articles.title: GPs asked to share views on physician associates in Leng review survey

articles.description: GP leaders in Wales have warned that the profession is facing an existential crisis across Britain - citing long-term underfunding and concerns over a looming hike in national insurance costs - and called for UK-wide collaboration on potential contract disputes.
articles.title: Existential crisis 'enveloping British general practice', warn LMCs

articles.description: Healthcare property company Assura - which owns hundreds of GP practice premises across the UK - could be set for a £1.61bn takeover after its board said it was 'minded to recommend' that shareholders accept a bid from private equity investors.
articles.title: Owner of hundreds of GP premises 'minded' to accept private equity takeover

articles.description: Black, Asian and ethnic minority patients experience 'alarming levels' of discrimination in NHS primary care services and report worse experiences of care, a report has found.
articles.title: Ethnic minority patients report worse experiences of primary care

articles.description: Alternatives to the traditional partnership model of general practice are desperately needed to stop practice closures and protect patient care as numbers of GP partners remain in freefall - but abolishing the model altogether would be the wrong approach, a think tank has warned.
articles.title: Government 'should develop alternative GP models' amid rapid decline in partners

articles.description: It is 'critical' for the government's forthcoming 10-year NHS plan to deliver immediate support for frontline GPs alongside longer-term proposals, GPs have warned.
articles.title: 10-year NHS plan must deliver immediate boost to general practice

articles.description: The GPonline team discusses what's in the GP contract for the coming year, what happens now with collective action, and the need for longer-term contract reform.
articles.title: Podcast: What does the 2025/26 GP contract mean for general practice?

articles.description: There is 'no convincing evidence' that physician associates add value in UK primary care, researchers have warned.
articles.title: 'No convincing evidence' physician associates add value in UK primary care

articles.description: The Scottish government should set up an 'umbrella body' to sponsor visas for international medical graduate (IMG) doctors who have completed UK GP training so that these doctors are not lost to the NHS, RCGP Scotland has said.
articles.title: Scottish GPs call for national fix to help IMG doctors secure visas

articles.description: Female doctors now outnumber their male counterparts for the first time in UK history - with general practice among the top three specialties with the highest proportion of women, the GMC has revealed.
articles.title: Majority of UK doctors are women - with GPs among specialties leading the way

articles.description: GP practices will be asked to deliver a new varicella vaccination programme from January 2026, providing the roll out is approved by the government.
articles.title: Chickenpox vaccination programme could launch in January 2026

articles.description: Nearly four in five GPs report feeling sleep deprived at work - with many warning tiredness has a direct impact on their ability to treat patients, a survey by a leading medico-legal organisation shows.
articles.title: Sleep-deprived GPs 'could be blamed unfairly' for errors in patient care

articles.description: GP leaders have agreed to pause collective action in general practice following the £969m contract uplift for 2025/26 - but what does that mean in practice, and what is on the line at the special LMCs conference scheduled for later this month?
articles.title: What does the pause in collective action really mean for GPs?

articles.description: Changes to the GP contract for 2025/26 that require practices to keep online consultation tools open throughout core hours will be a ‘nightmare’ and could put patients and doctors at risk, GPs have warned.
articles.title: Contract demand for online access throughout core hours 'a nightmare', GPs warn

articles.description: MIMS Learning Live Digital 2025 is your go-to free event for essential CPD learning, designed specifically for UK GPs, nurses and pharmacists.
articles.title: Practical learning and CPD from home

articles.description: From April 2025, rules that prevent the bulk of additional roles reimbursement scheme (ARRS) funding being used to recruit GPs will be scrapped - although eligibility will remain limited to GPs in their first two years post-qualification. GPonline looks at what the changes mean - and whether they are likely to bring an end to the jobs crisis that has left thousands of GPs struggling to find work.
articles.title: What is the future of ARRS - and can reform ease the GP jobs crisis?

articles.description: GP contract funding for 2025/26 could rise beyond the near-£1bn package announced last week if the Doctors and Dentists Review Body (DDRB) backs pay increases for general practice staff in excess of a basic 2.8% uplift built into the deal, NHS England has confirmed.
articles.title: GP funding for 2025/26 could rise further after DDRB advice

articles.description: GP practices will be required to publish a new patient charter on their websites under the 2025/26 GP contract, which sets out what people can expect from their practice.
articles.title: NHS England to create new GP 'patient charter' as part of 2025/26 contract

articles.description: Tight NHS finances will complicate the transfer of services from hospital to community settings, a senior doctor likely to become the next chair of NHS England has warned.
articles.title: Tight NHS finances make moving services into community harder, says Dash

articles.description: GPs in part of Scotland are taking on private work, moving overseas and in one case working as an Uber driver because locum sessions have become 'non-existent' after a squeeze on practice finances that doctors' leaders fear will spread across the country.
articles.title: Another GP working for Uber as jobs crisis spreads to Scotland

articles.description: GP leaders say the £1bn 2025/26 contract for general practice - backed provisionally this week by the BMA - will stop deterioration of services and could halt practice closures, but is only a first step towards transformative improvements in general practice.
articles.title: Contract uplift will 'stop the rot' but is only a first step, GPs warn

While […]

The online booking system opens today (Tuesday 25 March), for people to get a date in their diary for appointments starting from Tuesday 1 April. Those eligible for this year’s spring Covid-19 vaccine include adults […]

In the week ending 16 March, there were 899 hospital patients with norovirus – down from the winter peak of 1,160 seen in mid-February. Cases remain […]

The team – called the NHS Transformation Executive Team – will replace the current NHS England Executive Group and will support ongoing business priorities, statutory functions and day to day delivery. Except […]
articles.title: NHS England names new executive team to lead transition

articles.description: NHS staff have more than halved the average wait for tests and checks since the height of the pandemic as the waiting list continues to fall, new data shows today. Patients were waiting an average of 17 days for tests and checks in January – 43 days less than at the height of the pandemic […]
articles.title: NHS slashes tests and checks waits to 5-year low

articles.author: rwootton
articles.description: Thousands of NHS patients in England with multiple sclerosis (MS) are set to benefit from a life-changing ‘take at home’ tablet, as the NHS becomes the first healthcare system in Europe to roll it out widely to patients with active disease. The tablet, cladribine, requires just 20 days of treatment spread over four years, providing […]

Steve Russell, NHS national director for vaccinations and screening, said: “The NHS is contacting 5,261 people […]
articles.title: NHS England responds to ministerial statement on GP registration and screening issue

articles.description: NHS England has today announced changes to its leadership team, with three leading board members taking the decision to stand down at the end of March. Chief Financial Officer Julian Kelly, NHS Chief Operating Officer Emily Lawson and Chief Delivery Officer and National Director for Vaccination and Screening Steve Russell have today informed colleagues that […]
articles.title: NHS England board members stepping down

articles.author: rwootton
articles.description: The number of people being referred for specialist NHS support following rape or sexual assault has increased by nearly 18% in the last 2 years, NHS data suggests. NHS sexual assault referral centres – which provide free, specialist support to anyone across England who has been raped, sexually assaulted or abused – received over 26,000 […]
articles.title: Referrals to NHS sexual assault centres rise by 18% in 2 years

articles.description: Norovirus is continuing to pile pressure on NHS hospitals with over 40,000 bed days lost to the vomiting bug in February alone. The latest data shows there were 1,094 patients a day in hospital with norovirus last week, down slightly on the week before (1,134) but more than double the number of patients compared to […]
articles.title: Over 40,000 bed days lost To norovirus last month

articles.author: jboshell
articles.description: Professor Sir Stephen Powis, national medical director of NHS England has today announced that he will step down this summer, after over seven years in the role. Professor Powis notified Amanda Pritchard of his intention to stand down in a letter in January. He will continue until early July, focusing on the medical training review […]
articles.title: England’s top doctor to stand down after over seven years

articles.author: rwootton
articles.description: A new artificial intelligence (AI) tool is being rolled out across the NHS that can predict a patient’s risk of falling with 97% accuracy, preventing as many as 2,000 falls and hospital admissions each day. The predictive tool, developed by health tech provider Cera, is now being used in more than 2 million patient home […]
articles.title: Nationwide roll out of artificial intelligence tool that predicts falls and viruses

articles.description: NHS staff retention schemes have helped cut the number of workers leaving the health service to one of its lowest levels in over a decade, according to new analysis. 1 in 10 (10.1%) hospital and community healthcare workers left the NHS in the 12 months up to September 2024 – nearly 21,300 fewer than in […]
articles.title: Staff leaving the NHS among lowest in over a decade

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) today launched new guidance to help all countries reform and strengthen mental health policies and systems. Mental health services worldwide remain underfunded, with major gaps in access and quality. In some countries, up to 90% of people with severe mental health conditions receive no care at all, while many existing services rely on outdated institutional models that fail to meet international human rights standards.
The guidance provides a clear framework to transform mental health services in line with the latest evidence and international human rights standards, ensuring quality care is accessible to all.
"Despite rising demand, quality mental health services remain out of reach for many people," said Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, WHO Director-Gene…
articles.title: New WHO guidance calls for urgent transformation of mental health policies

articles.description: The WHO Technical Advisory Group on COVID-19 Vaccine Composition (TAG-CO-VAC) continues to closely monitor the genetic and antigenic evolution of SARS-CoV-2 variants, immune responses to SARS-CoV-2 infection and COVID-19 vaccination, and the performance of COVID-19 vaccines against circulating variants. Based on these evaluations, WHO advises vaccine manufacturers and regulatory authorities on the implications for future updates to COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition. The next decision-making meeting of the TAG-CO-VAC is scheduled for May 2025, after which a statement on COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition and an accompanying data annex will be published on the WHO website. These meetings are timed to balance the availability of the latest epidemiological, immunological, and virological …
articles.title: Types of data requested to inform May 2025 COVID-19 vaccine antigen composition deliberations

articles.description:
The number of children dying globally before their fifth birthday declined to 4.8 million in 2023, while stillbirths declined modestly, still remaining around 1.9 million, according to two new reports released today by the United Nations Inter-agency Group for Child Mortality Estimation (UN IGME).
Since 2000, child deaths have dropped by more than half and stillbirths by over a third, fuelled by sustained investments in child survival worldwide. In 2022, the world reached a historic milestone when child deaths dropped slightly below 5 million for the first time. However, progress has slowed and too many children are still being lost to preventable causes.

"Millions of children are alive today because of the global commitment to proven interventions, such as vaccines, nutrition, and access…
articles.title: Decades of progress in reducing child deaths and stillbirths under threat, warns the United Nations

articles.description:
On the occasion on World Tuberculosis (TB) Day, marked on 24 March, the World Health Organization (WHO) is calling for an urgent investment of resources to protect and maintain tuberculosis (TB) care and support services for people in need across regions and countries. TB remains the world’s deadliest infectious disease, responsible for over 1 million people annually bringing devastating impacts on families and communities. 
Global efforts to combat TB have saved an estimated 79 million lives since 2000. However, the drastic and abrupt cuts in global health funding happening now are threatening to reverse these gains. Rising drug resistance especially across Europe and the ongoing conflicts across the Middle-East, Africa and Eastern Europe, are further exacerbating the situation for the mo…
articles.title: WHO calls for urgent action to address worldwide disruptions in tuberculosis services putting millions of lives at risk

articles.description:
Today, during the annual Partnership for Healthy Cities Summit in Paris, three cities were recognized for their achievements in preventing noncommunicable diseases and injuries: Córdoba, Argentina; Fortaleza, Brazil; and Greater Manchester, United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. The Summit, co-hosted by Bloomberg Philanthropies, the World Health Organization (WHO), Vital Strategies, and the City of Paris, convened mayors and officials from 61 cities in the Partnership for Healthy Cities network to address pressing public health issues and share effective strategies for saving lives and building healthier communities at the local level.
“Noncommunicable diseases, including heart disease, cancer, and diabetes, and injuries are responsible for more than 80% of all deaths global…
articles.title: Three cities honoured for public health achievements at 2025 Partnership for Healthy Cities Summit

articles.description: Concurring with the advice unanimously expressed by the Committee during the meeting, the WHO Director-General determined that the upsurge of mpox 2024 continues to meet the criteria of a public health emergency of international concern (PHEIC).
articles.title: Third meeting of the International Health Regulations (2005) Emergency Committee regarding the upsurge of mpox 2024

articles.description: In an unprecedented show of unity, more than 47 million health professionals, patients, advocates, representatives from civil society organizations, and individuals worldwide have signed a resounding call for urgent action to reduce air pollution and to protect people’s health from its devastating impacts.
articles.title: Nearly 50 million people sign up call for clean air action for better health

articles.description:
Following recommendations by the World Health Organization (WHO), the United Nations Commission on Narcotic Drugs (CND) has decided to place five new psychoactive substances and one medicine under international control. 
The recommendations were developed by WHO Expert Committee on Drug Dependence--ECDD, which consists of global experts analyzing health risks and benefits of psychoactive substances circulating on global markets and alerting to include them under international control if evidence found that their use can cause harm for population health in countries. 
“These substances have been brought to WHO’s attention for being clandestinely manufactured, posing serious risk to public health and society without any recognized therapeutic use,” said Dr Deus Mubangizi, WHO Director for He…
articles.title: UN Commission approves WHO recommendations to place psychoactive substances under international control

articles.description:
In a three-day strategic dialogue, Belgium and WHO reviewed progress in their longstanding partnership, and agreed to further boost their collaboration on universal health coverage, health-systems strengthening and equitable access to essential vaccines, medicines and health technologies.

The Belgian delegation – headed by H.E. Christophe Payot, Ambassador of Belgium to the United Nations and other international organizations in Geneva – discussed issues of strategic importance, exchanged views on how to smoothly align WHO strategic directions and Belgium's development cooperation priorities in the context of an evolving global health landscape.
articles.title: Frank, in-depth discussion as Belgium and WHO map ahead priorities for collaboration

articles.description: WHO and Switzerland have announced the renewal of their cooperation strategy for the period 2024-2028. In 2013, Switzerland became the first high-income country in the WHO European Region to pilot a cooperation strategy with WHO (hereafter referred to as the WHO-Switzerland Cooperation Strategy). In 2022, WHO and Switzerland jointly decided to update and renew this cooperation strategy, done on 4 March 2025 at the Regional Office of the WHO in Copenhagen, Denmark.
articles.title: WHO and Switzerland cement cooperation until 2028

articles.description: Haemorrhage – severe heavy bleeding – and hypertensive disorders like preeclampsia are the leading causes of maternal deaths globally, according to a new study released today by the World Health Organization (WHO). These conditions were responsible for around 80 000 and 50 000 fatalities respectively in 2020 – the last year for which published estimates are available - highlighting that many women still lack access to lifesaving treatments and effective care during and after pregnancy and birth.
articles.title: Many pregnancy-related complications going undetected and untreated – WHO

articles.description:
The World Health Organization (WHO) today designated the Digital Ethics Centre at Delft University of Technology in the Netherlands as a WHO Collaborating Centre on artificial intelligence (AI) for health governance.  
AI has the potential to re-shape health care, save lives and improve health and well-being. However, harnessing its benefits for good requires collaboration from stakeholders committed to robust governance, ethical safeguards, and evidence-based policies. 
The WHO Collaborating Centre designation recognizes the Digital Ethics Centre at Delft University of Technology's decades-long history of cutting-edge research on responsible innovation, and its leadership in incorporating ethical values into design requirements for digital technologies. This inauguration marks the continu…
articles.title: WHO announces new collaborating centre on AI for health governance

articles.description: The Riyadh International Humanitarian Forum 2025 was a significant event that underscored the continued partnership between WHO and KSrelief, as well as with other international partners to address critical humanitarian health crises. The agreements made during the forum are pivotal in combating diseases like malaria, cholera, and polio, and ensuring better healthcare for displaced populations. The forum also highlighted Saudi Arabia’s ongoing commitment to global humanitarian efforts, reaffirming its leadership role in tackling some of the world’s pressing health crises.
articles.title: WHO and the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia sign agreements in support of health priorities
